title: ID headline typeface / Campaign magazine
content:
Could You help with ID Question?  
I know that is’s similar to Franklin or News Gothic, but...  
Especially lowercase g is strange.

(Picture is from page of Campaign magazine)

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [campaign\_type.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20080824070913/http:/typophile.com/files/campaign_type.jpg) | 73.25 KB |

 [‹ Font on a poster](http://web.archive.org/web/20080824070913/http:/typophile.com/node/39727 "Go to previous forum topic") [cadillac.. any one know what this font is? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080824070913/http:/typophile.com/node/39725 "Go to next forum topic")
author: bublick

comments.content:
I’d guess it may be a custom version of Monotype Grotesque, since it’s pretty similar to Monotype’s [Grotesque Display](http://web.archive.org/web/20080824070913/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/monotype/grotesque_display_bold_condensed/), which has a similar g, r and y (the r and y are much different in Bureau Grotesque, or Grotesque No. 9, for example).

- Mike Yanega

I guess once we start saying ’custom’, then any Gothic or Grotesque could be a candidate starting point, including Franklin Gothic.

What publication is this from? [edit: Duh! Read the post title Mike.]

- Mike Yanega

I Agree... maybe some modification of Franklin. But It would be great to know exact information.  
Bubl
